docs.lead_paragraph: Officials at the National Cancer Institute have begun to express frustration over their inability to reproduce the striking discoveries described a year ago by Dr. Judah Folkman, the Harvard researcher who reported that he and his colleagues had wiped out malignant tumors in mice by treating the animals with compounds that destroyed the tumors' blood supply. The institute's concerns were reported yesterday in a front-page article in The Wall Street Journal stating that Dr. Folkman's work had not passed an essential test of scientific validity: the requirement that it be reproduced by other researchers.

headline.main: A Failure to Verify A Cancer Advance Is Raising Concern

docs.abstract: Officials at National Cancer Institute are concerned that they have been unable to reproduce striking discoveries described year ago by Dr Judah Folkman, Harvard researcher who reported wiping out malignant tumors in mice by treating them with compounds that destroyed tumors' blod supply; institute, responding to Wall Street Journal report, says it will continue to study compounds, angiostatin and endostatin, in cooperation with Folkman's laboratory; Folkman says research takes time; Entremed, licensed to produce endostatin, says more than twenty company-sponsored studies have confirmed Folkman's findings (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As I enter the interviewing room, Charlie Chase is standing there alone, dressed in his tan prison scrubs and slip-on sneakers. We circle each other, and I'm a little wary at first, vaguely conscious of keeping the steel rectangular table between us in case he makes a sudden move in my direction. It's a feeling that's not eased by the circumstances of our visit, or by his record. Owing to what the authorities characterize as his ''poor interpersonal management skills,'' evidenced by a series of assaults on prisoners and guards, I have been advised not to get too close to Charlie, probably a poor idea to shake his hand, they said. A corrections officer has been posted just outside the smashproof glass door with orders to keep his eyes glued on our encounter. Not that Charlie appears able to do much damage at the moment. His feet are shackled by leg irons, and he's cuffed to a belly chain, so when I offer my hand finally, by instinct, he can extend his own only a few inches away from his body, in the manner of a flipper. The handshake seems to break the ice, and we smile quickly and sit down on swing-out stools at opposite ends of the table. Charlie starts off by apologizing for the way he looks, the scraggly patches of beard that he missed while shaving that morning. Unlike other prisoners, who shave during their showers, Charlie gets issued a razor only after he is escorted to an observation cell on the mental-health tier, or ''bug ward,'' and then must do the job hurriedly, with one hand chained, while a guard monitors his every movement.

headline.main: Is Solitary Confinement Driving Charlie Chase Crazy?

docs.abstract: Bruce Porter profile of Charlie Chase, considered one of most dangerous prison inmates in Massachusetts because of his attacks on other inmates, guards and self; he is being kept in solitary confinement in unit used to punish inmates for serious misconduct while in prison, treatment that appears to spur psychotic behavior; is part of class-action suit by unit inmates charging conditions cumulatively drive inmates insane; Chase comments, interview; photos (L)
